div.p: A DIALOGUE Between the FLAG OF St. MARTIN's Steeple, AND THE Standard AT THE TOWER.
LONDON, Printed by D.E. and fold by A. Baldwin, near the Oxford Arms in Warwick-Lane. MDCXCVIII.

div.head: TO THE Right Honourable JOHN Lord JEFFERYES, Baron of WEM, &c.
div.p:
THE Noble Character you are Maſter of, And the kind Reception your Lordſhip has been pleaſed to give to Things of this Nature has embolden'd me to make this Preſent to Your Lordſhip. And the Your Lordſhip's Hours are generall Employ'd in more ſerious Exerciſe
yet the Peruſal of ſo Trifling a Pamphlet, may ſo ſoften your more ſevere Studies, as it may be counted a Diverſion, if it cannot have the Name of a Pleaſure. My Lord, ſince the Corruption of the Age has been ſuch, as to render Things Animate ill employers of their Reaſon, it is but juſt that the Things which are Inanimate, ſhould ſerve as ſo many Inſtructions to 'em; and to give Beaſts, and Things void of Speech, the uſe of their Tongue, cannot be counted as Harm, ſince to take it from Man, who makes ſo ill uſe of it, would • arry the appearance of Juſtice with it. The two Flags which • rave Your Lordſhip's Acceptance, • ontend for Religion and Loyalty,
and I cannot but think I have done Juſtice to that of the Court, in making it prevail in the Diſpute, ſince the Church's has ſo far made a Forfeit of Both, as to have no very good Plea to Either. But, my Lord, there needs no giving your Lordſhip a light into my Deſign, who will but too ſoon (for its Author) give Your Judgment of it. All I have to do, is, to ask Your Lordſhip's Acceptance, and that You would be pleas'd to pardon the Deficiencies of,

closer.signed: Your Lordſhip's Moſt Obedient Servant. W. P.

div.head: A DIALOGUE Between the FLAG of St. Martin's Steeple, AND THE STANDARD at the TOWER.

lg.l: And Steeples, and Spires fall a Preaching;
To ſhew likewiſe their Talent of Speech in.
You have heard of the Drag—
Half a word is enough to the Wiſe;
And of ſuch a terrible Size!
Tho' I once was your Jeſt,
And the Subject of Mirth and your Laughter,
And I'm now made a Man for hereafter.
Is allow'd for a Place that is good:
Went to Halls to ſay Pray'rs,
It was almoſt as much as it cou'd.
I muſt needs tell you now,
I'm as good as your ſelf for the future,
Tho' you bear a great Name,
And our Qualities alſo ſhould ſuit here.
The Reſpect which is due to his Place,
And with Words ſo preſumptuous and baſe.
From the King's Royal Tower and Pallace.
You are plac'd on the Steeple,
Tho' you'd done as much good on the G—
And force Tythes and Reſpect from the Croud;
And takes on him ſome State,
Muſt the poor Pariſh-Clout too be proud?
Since I ſtand on a place that's divine,
Tho' I coſt not ſo many
Yet my Clout's a Flag as well as thine.
To make me look Great as I do:
And I think I ſay right,
I have done as much good full as you.
'Cauſe with Ditches and Guns ſo ſurrounded,
I have known Sir, a time,
Has thoſe Guns, and thoſe Ditches confounded:
Tho' commanded by ſtout Sir Ned Hales:
Made your Lace-coated Hero's turn Tails.
YEs, my Friend, that is certain,
Thou deſerv'ſt a great part in
The Bleſſings this Nation has bought:
Diſſent from the Doctrines they taught.
And with Bell, Book, and Candle,
A Text, which ſhould offer Denyal!
And the Tythe-Pigs were like to be ſeiz'd;
Turn their Yes, Yes, to No,
And their Hearers might do as they pleas'd.
A people the Church had quite Craz'd?
To lay part of the Duſt,
Which the Wind of your Pulpits had rais'd?
From ſuch Raga Muffins, it's certain,
Had Tower Flag had that Lyon
In thoſe times, as I on,
Let me tell you, a Fart for St. Martin.
YOu are much in the Wrong,
To a Church where a Prelate did Teach in:
Have an Excellent way in their preaching.
That holy Things will be the Fineſt:
And it is but in vain
To pretend to Cope with the Divineſt.
Yet Sir, tho' you ſtand on the Tower:
I am fix'd on a Place,
And ſhould have more Honour and power.
And I do you no wrong,
If I ſay that my Maſter is greater:
And I am in a Station,
Tho' I ſtand like a Fool here,
If I ſay, that your King does him ſerve.
I Muſt own Sir, it's true,
That the place which you ſtand on is holy;
But for you to lay claim,
It looks both like Madneſs and Folly.
Muſt a Flag of thoſe Bleſſings partake?
Be holy for that Place's ſake?
By my Troth, Sir, you'r out,
And fancying you'r e're a jot better,
Muſt it's Goodneſs belong to your Seat here?
And are very much out of the Road;
Says, Near the Church, is far from God.
And pretend to Religion, and Vertue?
Or Divinity there have a Party.
Or to deal in Religious Cares;
Lord! How Man with Lac'd Coat,
Should that Coat of his be at Pray'rs!
THat my Men in great Places,
And my Coats daub'd with Laces,
Don't pay much Reſpect to the Church,
And leave thoſe whom they guide in the Lurch.
To a Flag of my Force?
Prithee what didſt thou e're that was Good,
E're ſince on that Place thou haſt ſtood?
(For that is a Subject's Chief Glory)
As my Standard which Streams now before ye?
YEs, I think, Sir, much more,
To the beſt of my Pow'r,
I was always before-hand with you:
For the Joyful Spectators to view.
Thoſe Champions could give if they pleas'd.
With my Flag o • my Staffe
To think that our Side was the Winner.
And ſafely Secur'd the damn'd Sinner.
Would not give one poor Smile;
So far was your Standard from Laughter:
Or ſhow'd any Joy for the Matter.
Becauſe I took on me due State?
My Standard, in Matters not great?
May be Triumph enough for your Clout;
Will vouchſafe to Rejoyce or hang out.
But that I am moſt Loyal,
Since I ne'er yet have giv'n that Offence,
At the Birth, Sir, of you know what Prince.
Becauſe at that Time, I Sir,
Was in Being, which then you were not:
Had you then had your Birth,
You'd have ſhew'd as much Mirth,
As the reſt of us Flags, for a Pot.
Did as all of us did,
And kept as great pother, and Flutter'd:
For to put ſuch damn'd Slights
As a ſpurious Welch Heir, was a hard Caſe.
I had ne're been the firſt;
But I mightily love a whole Carcaſs.
And have been more Zealous and Hearty;
And another gueſs'd Monarch and Party.
If your Flag did not dare,
Might ne'r have made uſe of his Name.
DOne? By all that is holy,
Sure, your Reaſon, and Eyes too, are blind:
Were Vertues too bright for thy Mind.
As ſoon as the News came to Town,
And with Powder and Ball, knock'd 'em down?
Had Surrendred to His Majeſty's Troops,
To ſhew my Zeal and my Love,
And caus'd many Halloo's and Whoops.
In the mean while, you choſe
Till the News was Confirm'd by Expreſs.
And in Troth, Friend, how cou'd you do leſs?
To take News ſo on Truſt,
As your unadvis'd Rag has been wont;
But to Joy for a Peace
And let loſe your poor Flag for a Truce;
It look'd ſo much like an Abuſe?
And tho' the Peace was not then Sign'd,
Yet I knew that it muſt,
Muſt always fall out as Divin'd.
And he bad me deny't if I dar'd.
Confirm'd by my Teacher and Paſtor?
To ſo Knowing and Learned a Maſter?
BUt you ſaw, Friend, at laſt
And your poſitive Parſon had Err'd:
Pray, where had been the Harm,
And your Joys for ſome time had defer'd?
And made a moſt faithful Report
Which ſhould flow from the Peace,
And the Church been as true as the Court.
The Pride of your Soul at this time;
Or to think the Church Flag
Should impute to the Church any Crime.
And from all but the Great ones divided.
Since Pride won't let you know
By my Soul, Sir, you'd long ſince been mute.
